Key Arguments: The proposed legislation is not the appropriate way to address misinformation and disinformation.
Governments should focus on providing accurate information rather than suppressing dissenting views.
The legislation risks damaging public trust in government and scientific institutions.
There is a high risk of governments and social media providers getting things wrong, which could impair debate and damage public confidence.
The legislation could lead to costly and unproductive disputes and litigation.
The abrogation of the privilege against self-incrimination sets a dangerous precedent.
Main Themes: Freedom of speech and open debate
Concerns about precedent-setting in legal rights
Notable Quotes: It cannot be said too strongly that the proposed legislation is not the way to address these issues.
Ill-advised attempts to limit debate during the Covid-19 pandemic have already seriously damaged public confidence in scientists and in governments.
This sets an extremely dangerous precedent.
